Hat tips will follow for any resources I have used from others to help create them.

I have chosen 6 sections from the taxonomy to a task that gives a variation of questions on that particular topic.
1. Factual recall
2. Carry out a procedure
3. Classify a mathematical object
4. Prove, show, justify
5. Extend a concept
6. Criticize a fallacy

During the coming days I am going to create tasks called "Mixed Six" for each of key skills and cross over topics from Edexcel advance information.
This draw upon the work of Pointon and Sangwin's Taxonomy highlighted by @ChrisMcGrane84's excellent Task Design course 1/2 https://t.co/ojHcUEQH0e

Episodes - no particular order
- what should our curriculum focus on with reduced time due to pandemic?
- year 5 to 9 continuity
- developing problem solving
- developing reasoning
- supporting lower attainers
- enrichment and hinterland 
- consistency vs autonomy

2/2 These shorter episodes mean that we don't ramble, they can be used for CPD dept meetings or a commute to work and that there will be a variety of foci in each different episode. The CPD task will make thinking to action more likely.

1/2 ANNOUNCEMENT: I am planning on interviewing my first guest on my new "BAGs to Learn" podcast (nice use of my initials).
The first season will be on curriculum conversations - 45 mins talking about a focussed aspect of curriculum followed by the guest's choice of CPD task

Our half term 1 completion rate averages:
Year 11 -78% - 4 detentions held
Year 10 - 68% - 2 detentions held 
Year 9 - 67%
Year 8 - 64%
Year 7 - 80%

4/4

Holding students in detention on a Friday in one year group increased homework completion by 14% (after the detention where students did their task) but no real difference in figures before the detention I.e the threat didn‚Äôt deter. 3/n

Text messages to parents whose child had not completed it increased  on average by a further 7% (66% to 73%)
2/n

A thread on parental engagement and online homework in maths. 
We use @hegartymaths y8 - 11 and @TTRockStars y7 term 1. 
Sending an email/text message 2 days before maths homework was due increased Hegarty maths completion by 11% (60% to 71%) 1/n

@mrs_h_wig Yes if that is all that is set then I can see why. I think blended learning should have a personal touch too with teacher voice. Teaching is a social endeavour after all

To clarify, we are blending loom introductions with retrieval task or support from lesson before with Hegarty and opportunity to meet on G meet at the end of the week in ks4. In ks3, loom intros, white rose vid/work sheets and 3 Hegarty tasks at the end of the week for assessment

SLT: don‚Äôt punish maths teachers for their being a platform that provides guided practice to the tasks better than the teacher could, by asking them to dismiss the platform or reinvent the wheel. Instead ask them to start the lesson live or meet students virtually for Q&A 3/3

Yes, there is a social side to teaching that we all miss and value but there are alternatives to this rather than ALL live lessons or looms as a replacement. A blend of Hegarty and online Q&A sessions is fine if the task and video are well aligned with your curriculum 2/n

I don‚Äôt understand why some SLTs are so any Hegarty maths. There is a ‚Äúbusy culture‚Äù problem in education at times where it seems we need to justify all of our time. If you have Hegarty then you should only record videos if there isn‚Äôt a well matched video on the site imo 1/n

Using bar modelling to show the concepts of multiples and factors. The concept/non-concept slide draws on Engelmann's idea of sameness when introducing  a concept - keep the structure of the sentence stem invariant to draw attention to that which varies. https://t.co/Kti2cwVuG3

Moving away from generic CPD into departments does not mean that your CPD is now non-generic. If subject specific CPD is delivered generically it will have different impacts on staff and students depending on what staff already know/do. Blanket CPD exists at department level too

We then go away, practice, deliver and analyse the impact and come together to discuss, refresh each other on what we have been doing and gain support for our next steps. Really excited! CPD as it should be. Thread end    9/9

The other group will look at upcoming topics and learn about developing worked examples through guidance fading, task design, chaining, variation and concept/non-concept and develop tasks/examples for their future teaching. 8/n

1 group who weren't here for the training last year will be brought up to speed with bar modelling and how it can be applied across different topics that are upcoming including fractions, percentages, equations, factors and primes, ratio and scale, multiplicative reasoning 7/n

This means that the CPD time will have a direct impact on planning and delivery in the near future and is highly practical and personalised to staff development needs.
6/n

Tomorrow's session has a bespoke style, where staff choose to watch videos with attached tasks to complete on their chosen area, with opportunity to think about and try things out in upcoming lessons then analyze impact on student achievement. 5/n
Staff have chosen to develop worked examples, task design, variation, mathematical talk, use of CPA or developing problem solving in topics they are about to teach 4/n

A choice is important for staff in terms of motivation; a guided choice is important so staff don't suffer from 'choice paralysis' and choose something that is already well developed in their practice or will not have a big enough impact on student achievement. 3/n
Each member has chosen an area to develop this year from a menu that supports the implementation of ideas that we were trained on last year through @WRMathsSec Jigsaw training. 2/n

Thread: I am really excited about our CPD programme in our department this year - we are moving away from the generic whole school pedagogy focus and into subject specific, collaborative, curriculum focussed time. 1/n

@MrMattock @StudyMaths @EmathsUK Just the words you use that‚Äôs all. Is multiplying by 1 a ‚Äúflip‚Äù of the tiles?

@StudyMaths @MrMattock @EmathsUK 13/13 Finally, this is definitely the best way in with students in terms of manipulatives and has more flexibility than bar modelling in my opinion. The students are making better early decisions than previously when I have taught this topic abstractly. #mathschat

@StudyMaths @MrMattock @EmathsUK 11/n Once students got used to this, we talked about how we could use this in our language when thinking and trying to picture the set up without it being physical - a sort of exit strategy from the manipulative.

@StudyMaths @MrMattock @EmathsUK 10/n growing the equations in complexity by adding in larger numbers that are more difficult to represent with algebra tiles, fractions (both as a solution and as part of the terms in the equations) and negative numbers help with this

8/n Interested to hear what language people who are more expert than me use when they are faced with -5y=15 with algebra tiles? @StudyMaths @MrMattock @EmathsUK 
Also interested how, without physically cutting the tiles, one might show y/2=4 using the tiles?

7/n I see teachers showing 3y+4=16 as an example and then give LOTS of these equations in this form as practice with the idea that "massed practice" helps muscle memory. I feel this idea is flawed and would rather spend more time in the I do, we do phase to show this variation

6/n Ask what it questions at all times... y + 2 = 11
What if I changed this to 2 + y = 11 or 11 = y + 2.
By showing the different ways an equation can be written, allows students to better understand the underlying structure of the equation when it is written differently

5/n this idea breaks down when you are trying to form a zero pair with a negative term. "Removal" from both sides doesn't work so what is the point in teaching something that is not easily generalised?

4/n balancing both sides and the language you use is key. It is more useful to talk about subtraction as the additive inverse than "taking from both sides." While it feels ok to just remove positive tiles from both sides...
3/n getting students used to solving 1 step equations involving multiplication, addition and subtraction with the tiles is really important.
2/n I found it really practical to use really small numbers with my examples so that students had enough tiles and could assemble the representation quickly.
